question.text: The temperature dependence of resistance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Cu</mi></math> and undoped <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Si</mi></math> in the temperature range <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>300</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>400</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math> is best described by

options.text: linear increase for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Cu</mi></math>, exponential decrease for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Si</mi></math>
linear decrease for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Cu</mi></math>, linear decrease for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Si</mi></math>
linear increase for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Cu</mi></math>, linear increase for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Si</mi></math>
linear increase for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Cu</mi></math>, exponential increase for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Si</mi></math>

solution.text: Resistance variation with temperature: resistance of a metal increases with increase in temperature linearly and resistance of a semiconductor decreases exponentially with increase in temperature.
